     104              : // BORINGSSL_API_VERSION is a positive integer that increments as BoringSSL

     142              : // OPENSSL_DEPRECATED is used to mark a function as deprecated. Use

     144              : // OPENSSL_BEGIN_ALLOW_DEPRECATED and OPENSSL_END_ALLOW_DEPRECATED

     199              : #define OPENSSL_UNUSED __attribute__((unused))
     200              : #else
     201              : #define OPENSSL_UNUSED
     202              : #endif
     203              : 
     204              : // C and C++ handle inline functions differently. In C++, an inline function is
     205              : // defined in just the header file, potentially emitted in multiple compilation
     206              : // units (in cases the compiler did not inline), but each copy must be identical
     207              : // to satsify ODR. In C, a non-static inline must be manually emitted in exactly
     208              : // one compilation unit with a separate extern inline declaration.
     209              : //
     210              : // In both languages, exported inline functions referencing file-local symbols
     211              : // are problematic. C forbids this altogether (though GCC and Clang seem not to
     212              : // enforce it). It works in C++, but ODR requires the definitions be identical,
     213              : // including all names in the definitions resolving to the "same entity". In
     214              : // practice, this is unlikely to be a problem, but an inline function that
     215              : // returns a pointer to a file-local symbol
     216              : // could compile oddly.
     217              : //
     218              : // Historically, we used static inline in headers. However, to satisfy ODR, use
     219              : // plain inline in C++, to allow inline consumer functions to call our header
     220              : // functions. Plain inline would also work better with C99 inline, but that is
     221              : // not used much in practice, extern inline is tedious, and there are conflicts
     222              : // with the old gnu89 model:
     223              : // https://stackoverflow.com/questions/216510/extern-inline
     224              : #if defined(__cplusplus)
     225              : #define OPENSSL_INLINE inline
     226              : #else
     227              : // Add OPENSSL_UNUSED so that, should an inline function be emitted via macro
     228              : // (e.g. a |STACK_OF(T)| implementation) in a source file without tripping
     229              : // clang's -Wunused-function.
     230              : #define OPENSSL_INLINE static inline OPENSSL_UNUSED
     231              : #endif
     232              : 
     233              : #if defined(__cplusplus)
     234              : // enums can be predeclared, but only in C++ and only if given an explicit type.
     235              : // C doesn't support setting an explicit type for enums thus a #define is used
     236              : // to do this only for C++. However, the ABI type between C and C++ need to have
     237              : // equal sizes, which is confirmed in a unittest.
     238              : #define BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT : int
     239              : enum ssl_early_data_reason_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;
     240              : enum ssl_encryption_level_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;
     241              : enum ssl_private_key_result_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;
     242              : enum ssl_renegotiate_mode_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;
     243              : enum ssl_select_cert_result_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;
     244              : enum ssl_select_cert_result_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;
     245              : enum ssl_ticket_aead_result_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;
     246              : enum ssl_verify_result_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;
     247              : #else
     248              : #define BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT
     249              : #endif
     250              : 
     251              : // ossl_ssize_t is a signed type which is large enough to fit the size of any
     252              : // valid memory allocation. We prefer using |size_t|, but sometimes we need a
     253              : // signed type for OpenSSL API compatibility. This type can be used in such
     254              : // cases to avoid overflow.
     255              : //
     256              : // Not all |size_t| values fit in |ossl_ssize_t|, but all |size_t| values that
     257              : // are sizes of or indices into C objects, can be converted without overflow.
     258              : typedef ptrdiff_t ossl_ssize_t;

     397              : // BSSL_CHECK aborts if |condition| is not true.
     398              : #define BSSL_CHECK(condition) \
     399              :   do {                        \
     400              :     if (!(condition)) {       \
     401              :       abort();                \
     402              :     }                         \
     403              :   } while (0);
     404              : 
     405              : #if defined(__cplusplus)
     406              : }  // extern C
     407              : #elif !defined(BORINGSSL_NO_CXX)
     408              : #define BORINGSSL_NO_CXX
     409              : #endif
     410              : 
     411              : #if defined(BORINGSSL_PREFIX)
     412              : #define BSSL_NAMESPACE_BEGIN \
     413              :   namespace bssl {           \
     414              :   inline namespace BORINGSSL_PREFIX {
     415              : #define BSSL_NAMESPACE_END \
     416              :   }                        \
     417              :   }
     418              : #else
     419              : #define BSSL_NAMESPACE_BEGIN namespace bssl {
     420              : #define BSSL_NAMESPACE_END }
     421              : #endif
     422              : 
     423              : // MSVC doesn't set __cplusplus to 201103 to indicate C++11 support (see
     424              : // https://connect.microsoft.com/VisualStudio/feedback/details/763051/a-value-of-predefined-macro-cplusplus-is-still-199711l)
     425              : // so MSVC is just assumed to support C++11.
     426              : #if !defined(BORINGSSL_NO_CXX) && __cplusplus < 201103L && !defined(_MSC_VER)

     444              : #if defined(BORINGSSL_NO_CXX)
     445              : 
     446              : #define BORINGSSL_MAKE_DELETER(type, deleter)
     447              : #define BORINGSSL_MAKE_UP_REF(type, up_ref_func)
     448              :

     450              : 
     451              : extern "C++" {
     452              : 
     453              : BSSL_NAMESPACE_BEGIN
     454              : 
     455              : namespace internal {
     456              : 
     457              : // The Enable parameter is ignored and only exists so specializations can use
     458              : // SFINAE.
     459              : template <typename T, typename Enable = void>
     460              : struct DeleterImpl {};
     461              : 
     462              : struct Deleter {
     463              :   template <typename T>
     464            1 :   void operator()(T *ptr) {
     465              :     // Rather than specialize Deleter for each type, we specialize
     466              :     // DeleterImpl. This allows bssl::UniquePtr<T> to be used while only
     467              :     // including base.h as long as the destructor is not emitted. This matches
     468              :     // std::unique_ptr's behavior on forward-declared types.
     469              :     //
     470              :     // DeleterImpl itself is specialized in the corresponding module's header
     471              :     // and must be included to release an object. If not included, the compiler
     472              :     // will error that DeleterImpl<T> does not have a method Free.
     473            1 :     DeleterImpl<T>::Free(ptr);
     474            1 :   }
     475              : };
     476              : 
     477              : template <typename T, typename CleanupRet, void (*init)(T *),
     478              :           CleanupRet (*cleanup)(T *)>
     479              : class StackAllocated {
     480              :  public:
     481              :   StackAllocated() { init(&ctx_); }
     482              :   ~StackAllocated() { cleanup(&ctx_); }
     483              : 
     484              :   StackAllocated(const StackAllocated &) = delete;
     485              :   StackAllocated& operator=(const StackAllocated &) = delete;
     486              : 
     487              :   T *get() { return &ctx_; }
     488              :   const T *get() const { return &ctx_; }
     489              : 
     490              :   T *operator->() { return &ctx_; }
     491              :   const T *operator->() const { return &ctx_; }

     494              :     cleanup(&ctx_);
     495              :     init(&ctx_);
     496              :   }
     497              : 
     498              :  private:
     499              :   T ctx_;
     500              : };

     503              :           CleanupRet (*cleanup)(T *), void (*move)(T *, T *)>

     532              : 
     533              : }  // namespace internal
     534              : 
     535              : #define BORINGSSL_MAKE_DELETER(type, deleter)     \
     536              :   namespace internal {                            \
     537              :   template <>                                     \
     538              :   struct DeleterImpl<type> {                      \
     539            1 :     static void Free(type *ptr) { deleter(ptr); } \
     540              :   };                                              \
     541              :   }
     542              : 
     543              : // Holds ownership of heap-allocated BoringSSL structures. Sample usage:
     544              : //   bssl::UniquePtr<RSA> rsa(RSA_new());
     545              : //   bssl::UniquePtr<BIO> bio(BIO_new(BIO_s_mem()));
     546              : template <typename T>
     547              : using UniquePtr = std::unique_ptr<T, internal::Deleter>;
     548              : 
     549              : #define BORINGSSL_MAKE_UP_REF(type, up_ref_func)             \
     550            0 :   inline UniquePtr<type> UpRef(type *v) {                    \
     551            0 :     if (v != nullptr) {                                      \
     552            0 :       up_ref_func(v);                                        \
     553            0 :     }                                                        \
     554            0 :     return UniquePtr<type>(v);                               \
     555            0 :   }                                                          \
     556              :                                                              \
     557            0 :   inline UniquePtr<type> UpRef(const UniquePtr<type> &ptr) { \
     558            0 :     return UpRef(ptr.get());                                 \
     559            0 :   }
     560              : 
     561              : BSSL_NAMESPACE_END
     562              : 
     563              : }  // extern C++
